dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, we've been hearing a lot about digital currencies, right? And Zuckerberg, uh, really stirred the pot suggesting a Chinese digital currency could undermine the dollar's global dominance.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, we've been hearing a lot about digital currencies, right? And Zuckerberg, uh, really stirred the pot suggesting a Chinese digital currency could undermine the dollar's global dominance.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Perhaps Zuckerberg went too far when he suggested that the imminent rise of a Chinese digital currency could undermine overall dollar dominance of global trade and finance at least the large part that is legal, taxed, and regulated.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, I saw that. And, like, my initial thought was, "Is he going too far?" I mean, the US has *immense* power, you know, over global finance. We've seen it with European banks and Iran.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, I saw that. And, like, my initial thought was, Is he going too far? I mean, the U S has immense power, you know, over global finance. We've seen it with European banks and Iran.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In fact, US regulators have vast power not only over domestic entities but also over any financial firms that need access to dollar markets, as Europe recently learned to its dismay when the US forced European banks to comply with severe restrictions on doing business with Iran.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right, right. For the *legal* stuff, absolutely. Our deep markets, strong institutions... that's hard to beat. China's got those capital controls and, like, a pretty opaque system.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, right. For the legal stuff, absolutely. Our deep markets, strong institutions... that's hard to beat. China's got those capital controls and, like, a pretty opaque system.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Americas deep and liquid markets, its strong institutions, and the rule of law will trump Chinese efforts to achieve currency dominance for a long time to come. Chinas burdensome capital controls, its limits on foreign holdings of bonds and equities, and the general opaqueness of its financial system leave the renminbi many decades away from supplanting the dollar in the legal global economy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. So, for the mainstream, regulated economy, the dollar's pretty safe for a long time. They're decades away from challenging it there.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. So, for the mainstream, regulated economy, the dollar's pretty safe for a long time. They're decades away from challenging it there.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Chinas burdensome capital controls, its limits on foreign holdings of bonds and equities, and the general opaqueness of its financial system leave the renminbi many decades away from supplanting the dollar in the legal global economy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But... what about the *other* side of the coin, B? The underground economy? Tax evasion, criminal stuff, terrorism. It's smaller, sure, but still hugely consequential.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But... what about the other side of the coin, B? The underground economy? Tax evasion, criminal stuff, terrorism. It's smaller, sure, but still hugely consequential.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The global underground economy, consisting mainly of tax evasion and criminal activities, but also terrorism, is much smaller than the legal economy (perhaps one-fifth the size), but it is still highly consequential.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Hmm, that's interesting. Because, I mean, a state-backed Chinese digital currency there... [interrupts]
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hmm, that's interesting. Because, I mean, a state-backed Chinese digital currency there...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Could be a real issue! Especially where their interests just don't align with ours.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Could be a real issue! Especially where their interests just don't align with ours.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And a widely used, state-backed Chinese digital currency could certainly have an impact, especially in areas where Chinas interests do not coincide with those of the West.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, because if it's US-regulated, we could, like, track it. Imagine North Korea trying to pay scientists, or Iran funding terrorism â€“ *poof*, traceable.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, because if it's U S-regulated, we could, like, track it. Imagine North Korea trying to pay scientists, or Iran funding terrorism - poof, traceable.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A US-regulated digital currency could in principle be required to be traceable by US authorities, so that if North Korea were to use it to hire Russian nuclear scientists, or Iran were to use it to finance terrorist activity, they would run a high risk of being caught, and potentially even blocked.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But if China's running it? Suddenly, our levers are way fewer. We could ban it, sure, but that won't stop it in large parts of Africa or Latin America.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But if China's running it? Suddenly, our levers are way fewer. We could ban it, sure, but that won't stop it in large parts of Africa or Latin America.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If, however, the digital currency were run out of China, the US would have far fewer levers to pull. Western regulators could ultimately ban the use of Chinas digital currency, but that wouldnt stop it from being used in large parts of Africa, Latin America, and Asia, which in turn could engender some underground demand even in the US and Europe.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. And then you get underground demand even here in the US and Europe. So, why not just use Bitcoin then, you know?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. And then you get underground demand even here in the U S and Europe. So, why not just use Bitcoin then, you know?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...which in turn could engender some underground demand even in the US and Europe.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, Bitcoin, and other cryptos, they're, uh, heavily proscribed. Regulators make them super illiquid. A state-backed one, though? It could actually be *spent* in one of the world's largest economies.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, Bitcoin, and other cryptos, they're, uh, heavily proscribed. Regulators make them super illiquid. A state-backed one, though? It could actually be spent in one of the world's largest economies.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But regulators worldwide have huge incentives to rein in cryptocurrencies by sharply proscribing their use in banks and retail establishments. Such restrictions make existing cryptocurrencies highly illiquid and ultimately greatly limit their fundamental underlying value. Not so for a Chinese-backed digital renminbi that could readily be spent in one of the worlds two largest economies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Ah, I see. So the key is the backing, and the usability. Even if China's version is "permissioned" and they see everything...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Ah, I see. So the key is the backing, and the usability. Even if China's version is permissioned and they see everything...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: True, when China announces its new digital currency, it will almost surely be permissioned: a central clearing house will in principle allow the Chinese government to see anything and everything.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right, *they* see everything, but *we* wouldn't, not directly. It's a whole different ballgame.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, they see everything, but we wouldn't, not directly. It's a whole different ballgame.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And Libra, Facebook's thing, that's permissioned too, but it's under Swiss regulators and pegged to the dollar. So, we'd have more insight there.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Libra, Facebook's thing, that's permissioned too, but it's under Swiss regulators and pegged to the dollar. So, we'd have more insight there.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Facebooks Libra is also designed as a permissioned currency, in its case under the auspices of Swiss regulators. ... The fact that Libra will be pegged to the US dollar will give US authorities additional insight, because (at present) all dollar clearing must go through US-regulated entities.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but is there really *fundamental* demand for Libra, unless you're trying to, um, avoid detection? It's not *that* much better than existing financial instruments.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but is there really fundamental demand for Libra, unless you're trying to, um, avoid detection? It's not that much better than existing financial instruments.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Still, given that Libras functionality can largely be duplicated with existing financial instruments, it is hard to see much fundamental demand for Libra except among those aiming to evade detection.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Fair point. But it *has* spurred other central banks to accelerate their own digital currency programs, which is good.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Fair point. But it has spurred other central banks to accelerate their own digital currency programs, which is good.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If nothing else, Libra has inspired many advanced-economy central banks to accelerate their programs to provide broader-based retail digital currencies, and, one hopes, to strengthen their efforts to boost financial inclusion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. But ultimately, this isn't just about printing currency. It's about the state's power to regulate, to tax, and for the US, to use the dollar for foreign policy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. But ultimately, this isn't just about printing currency. It's about the state's power to regulate, to tax, and for the U S, to use the dollar for foreign policy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But this battle is not simply over the profits from printing currency; ultimately, it is over the states ability to regulate and tax the economy in general, and over the US governments ability to use the dollars global role to advance its international policy aims.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. Like the sanctions we've seen on Turkey or Russia. This tech is disrupting our ability to leverage our currency to pursue national interests.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. Like the sanctions we've seen on Turkey or Russia. This tech is disrupting our ability to leverage our currency to pursue national interests.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The US currently has financial sanctions in place against 12 countries. Turkey was briefly sanctioned last month after its invasion of Kurdish territory in Syria, though the measures were quickly lifted. For Russia, sanctions have been in place for five years. Just as technology has disrupted media, politics, and business, it is on the verge of disrupting Americas ability to leverage faith in its currency to pursue its broader national interests.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, Libra might not be *the* answer, but if Western governments don't figure something out soon, we're in big trouble.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, Libra might not be the answer, but if Western governments don't figure something out soon, we're in big trouble.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Libra is probably not the answer to the coming disruption posed by government-sanctioned digital currencies from China and elsewhere. But if not, Western governments need to start thinking about their response now, before it is too late.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely. We need a response, and fast.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely. We need a response, and fast.
